boardgame.name: 2020: Extension Pack +
boardgame.description:
A game designed for those that wish to leave 2020 behind! Create your circle of friends to help you survive the financial hardships of 2020. Do whatever it takes to survive this year above the rest but remember: Problematic players lose their jobs, sponsorships, friends and sometimes even money.

Players gain survival points based on the cards that they play, and when a player has acquired fifteen survival points, the end of the game is triggered. At the end of that round, players count their money and the player with the most money wins.

With the 2020: Extension Pack +, players will encounter 52 exclusive social media cards that give players the a chance to look back and laugh at the monstrosity of 2020.

—description from the designer

listing.notes: If you'd like to get a copy of the game and if you're international or you'd like this item at a discounted rate go to the official website https://2020boardgame.co DM me if your country isn't open, I can open it for you!

boardgame.name: Yankee ASL Nor'easter Pack II
boardgame.description:
3 New ASL Boards and 15 scenarios designed by the Yankee ASL'ers, a group of ASL players in the Boston area. This scenario pack has no particular theme and stretches from a Polish scenario in September 1939, through the Korean war in 1950, and the French Indochina war in 1954.

This is a follow on to the 20th Anniversary Scenario pack which was produced in 2016 for tournament play, but this time the pack was produced and sold by Le Franc Tireur.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

listing.notes:
From Le Franc Tireur.
Here is a new product from the new England ASLERs ! This is from the same producers who brought you the YASL pack a few years ago. This time they had LFT produce the pack. It features 3 boards and 15 scenarios.
New Buyer pays shipping will combine multiple purchase

boardgame.name: Pumpkin Killer Man
boardgame.description:
A card game based on a simple turn by turn system, on your turn turning over cards to find villagers, to gain points, but if you draw Pumpkin Killer Man, you're dead! Try to save the people of Fallville, and get out alive. This game includes many different ways to play and extra rules to add mechanics to the base style of play.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Forgotten Battles from France to Germany: January to April 1945
boardgame.description:
This book contains 23 battle scenarios, covering the period of January to April 1945. It also includes special rules for each scenario.

New weapons, armour and infantry types can be applied to any set of rules. Including War on the Ground.

If you are under the impression that the last few months of the Second World War in Western Europe was a ‘walk in the park’, this book will prove otherwise!

Some of the hardest fighting took place from January to April 1945 and here you will find historical battles, which most will not have come across before.
The scenarios are testing and will be a challenge for all wargamers.

–description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: The War on the Ground: World War 2 Wargame Rules

boardgame.name: Only Cans
OnlyCans
boardgame.description: OnlyCans puts you as the principal photographer of each different drink.

boardgame.name: 30 Days of Mork Bork Adventure Chapbook Vol. 1
boardgame.description:
Designer summary

Forty-four pages of madness and mayhem to make your players suffer in The Dying World! Plumb the depths of Death's Fort in search of the riches hidden within. Scale the volcano of The Shattered Tunnels to take on the evil Blood Wizard. Wander the Sarkash in search of The Shrine of Evil. Three unique offerings for MÖRK BORG consisting of a procedurally generated dungeon, a point crawl, and a hex crawl; all in one tome.

boardgame.name: The Augur - Ironsworn VTT
boardgame.description:
Designer summary

A virtual tabletop for solo RPGs, play and create amazing stories using a game designed to immerse you in the narrative and stimulate your creativity. Maps, scenes, battles, Avatars, Portraits, Oracles, Tables, journals, notebooks, Equipment, Items, and Enemies. The Augur has everything. Based on the amazing Ironsworn RPG and limited only by your own imagination, there is nothing you cannot do in this game.

boardgame.name: Misery - Mork Bork VTT
boardgame.description:
Designer summary

A virtual tabletop for solo RPGs, play and create amazing stories using a game designed to immerse you in the narrative and stimulate your creativity. Maps, scenes, battles, Avatars, Portraits, Oracles, Tables, journals, notebooks, Equipment, Items, and Enemies. The Augur has everything. Based on the amazing Ironsworn RPG and limited only by your own imagination, there is nothing you cannot do in this game.

boardgame.name: One Page Bayhem
boardgame.description:
> I knock on the door of my mom's house.

> Roll to see if it explodes!





One Page Bayhem is a one-page roleplaying game designed to parodize a Michael Bay movie. It's balanced to be unbalanced and results in totally explosive antics.

There's a page for everyone containing the rules and a GM Guide to help the GM run the game, including instant setup dieroll tables.

You only need a d6.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Nebs 'n Debs
boardgame.description:
Nebs 'n Debs is a new game for the original Nintendo Entertainment System. Run, jump, and dash your way through 12 levels as you search for the missing parts of Debs's ship to escape the hostile alien planet Vespasian 7MV! Nebs 'n Debs runs on the same type of game cartridge as the original Super Mario Bros.

Features
12 unique levels
HAAAAARRRRRDDDDDDDDD Mode (unlocked after beating all 12 levels)
Run-jump-dashing-platforming-crystal-collecting action

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Wart Worm Wingding
boardgame.description:
Wart Worm Wingding is a 2-player arcade adventure for the NES. It's inspired by games like Bubble Bobble and Dig Dug.

The settlers' mining operations have gone too far. Help the Wart Worms, Wing and Ding, destroy the settler invaders and free their underground lands from exploitation!

Wart Worm Wingding features a rocking soundtrack, over 100 levels, and 10 boss fights.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Wampus
boardgame.description:
Wampus is an overhead arcade narrative adventure game developed for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES).

The wampus live on a planet invaded by colonialists, who farm and mine the land for its natural resources. These resource-stripping activities threaten the local flora and fauna, especially the Mountain Wampus, who get hunted for their treasure.

As a young wampus, players set out to rid the planet of the settler invaders and restore harmony to the land. While a fun lark, Wampus explores themes of environmentalism, conservationism, stewardship of the land, and the destructive nature of colonialism.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Bat Lizard Bonanza
boardgame.description:
Bat Lizard Bonanza is an arcade shoot-em-up (or shmup) for the NES. It's inspired by games like Gradius and Parodius.

The settlers have been exploiting Irata’s natural resources for many solar cycles. The Wampus took back the mountains. The Wart Worms took back the mines. But now Lizzy the Bat Lizard must embark on a quest to end the Settler scourge once and for all, dauntless in the wind with the echoes of her ancestors at her back.

Bat Lizard Bonanza features a rocking soundtrack, seven levels, and over 14 boss fights.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Leggite Luta Livre
boardgame.description:
Leggite Luta Livre is an arcade beat-em-up for the Nintendo Entertainment System.

One hundred solar cycles have passed since the three-front revolution on Irata that overturned settler rule and led to a new era of peace and prosperity for all the native creatures of the planet.

In this time, some of the former colonists who remained on Irata have settled down. The Leggites developed martial arts and now live in peace with the local fauna. But the spheroids have turned to organized crime.

Their boss, Chunga, uses violent thugs to control his territory and keep a boot on the neck of the local population. Chunga thought he was untouchable. And he might have been.

But then he decided to mess with Leggette and her family.

This game features five missions. Players have a dynamic set of moves that include a standard kick, a jump kick, and a roll maneuver that can be combined in unique ways to create engaging combat encounters. Players can also pick up two projectile items that further extend combat choices.

There are eight unique boss battles, multiple enemy types, and an entire alien world to explore and liberate. You are Leggette. Your child has been kidnapped by an evil mob boss. It's time to clean up the streets of Irata.


Note: While a 2-player mode is selectable from the title screen, that mode is not currently in the game. This will be added in a future update.


Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: 英雄对决 (Hero Battle)
boardgame.description:
GAME SYSTEM



This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.




A trading card game published by Chinese collectible card publisher Kayou.
In this game, players can use heros from Ultraman Universe or Marvel Universe to fight with the opponent.
At the start of the game, each player draw 9 cards and set 5 of them on the field, other 4 cards are their hand. In each turn, player should choose a card on the field to fight the opponent, the player who has 5 heroes defeated will lose the game.

So far, the series has published two Marvel basic packs and two Ultraman basic packs, as well as three Marvel booster packs and two Ultraman booster packs.

boardgame.name: Insurmountable
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Insurmountable is an adventure game, where the player has to overcome huge mountains.

boardgame.name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition): Broken Realms – Be'lakor
boardgame.description:
While the Mortal Realms rage under the fires of countless wars, one scorned figure looks to take advantage and further his unknowable agenda. Be'lakor, the Dark Master, whose schemes have had their twisted tendrils in many momentous events, begins to enact the final stages of his grand ambition. With the beleaguered Stormcast who followed Morathi into the Eightpoints making their retreat back across the Bloodwind Spoil, and the Seraphon beginning their own assault upon Archaon's realm, what could the first and greatest of the Daemon Princes have in store?

The third instalment in the Broken Realms series sees the hidden machinations of Be'lakor come to the fore as the Dark Master begins to take a more direct role in the Mortal Realms' events. The dire consequences will ripple across multiple factions, including an unforeseen alliance between Chaos and Death, the march of the Seraphon's Celestial Stampede, and the introduction of siege warfare to Warhammer Age of Sigmar.

Inside this 112-page hardback book, you'll find:


The chilling tale of Be'lakor's grand plan to usurp the Everchosen and take his place as the foremost champion of Chaos



Rules for the Legion of the First Prince, including an expanded warscroll for Be'lakor himself and updated battle traits, spells and artefacts for his Slaves to Darkness warband



Coalition of Death rules allowing you to play team-based games including 3 or more players, who may need to team up temporarily to take out a threatening foe while keeping an eye out for their so-called 'allies'



Six battleplans to help you recreate pivotal moments from the story, as well as Realms of Battle rules to represent the unique locations they were fought in



Rules to tie the battleplans into a narrative campaign depicting Be'lakor's assault upon the Mortal Realms



A bounty of warscrolls, warscroll battalions and unit updates for Kharadron Overlords, Fyreslayers, Stormcast Eternals, Disciples of Tzeentch, Nighthaunt, and Seraphon


—description from the publisher
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition): Broken Realms – Kragnos
Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition) Core Rules
Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition): Broken Realms – Teclis

boardgame.name: Dull Grey
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Dull Grey is a visual novel set in a dystopian world. The visuals style tracing back to Soviet graphics of the 20s.

boardgame.name: Twin Dragons
boardgame.description:
On a far away island, Dinky and Minky, the Twin Dragons, live on top of a mountain with their parents, waiting for their new sibling to hatch out. One day, while their parents went hunting, the sorcerer of the neighboring remote tribe’s village decided to steal the egg in order to increase his power.

Help Dinky and Minky on their fantastic journey to rescue the Precious !

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Shroom Shroom!
boardgame.description:
Buy, sell, and trade all kinds of crazy mushrooms on your way to victory in this exciting, strategic, and family-friendly card game.

—user summary

Shroom Shroom is a super fun and strategic card game about collecting and trading all kinds of crazy mushrooms. Players take turns selling, buying, and trading mushrooms to add to their collections. Try and collect different combinations and families of mushrooms to earn points.

Choose your cards wisely because you can only have up to ten shrooms in your collection at a time. Some cards have special powers that allow you to develop fun or cruel strategies against each other. The thing that makes Shroom Shroom even more awesome is trading. You can trade anything with anyone at any time during the game. While you're waiting for your turn, make some trades with other players to help build up your collection.

When the cards run out, everyone adds up their points and the person with the best shroom collection wins.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Escaping The Orcs: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
In Escaping The Orcs, you control a group of human slaves trying to escape from their Orcish oppressors.
The game is played over four scenarios as you escape and then search for a safe home while being pursued by angry Orcs.

Ideal for 28mm figures but any scale will do as long as they are individually based.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Sci-Fi Return: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
In Sci-Fi Return, you must enter a damaged space station and recover some information.
The station is in danger of falling apart and various dangerous creatures have escaped and are roaming the facility.

This is a sequel to Sci-Fi Escape but is a stand alone game you don't need anything else to play it.

Ideal for 28mm figures but you can use whatever comes to hand.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Goblin Trek 2: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
In Goblin Trek 2 you must bring your party of Goblins to safety while being pursued by Orcs through a hostile desert.

A solo game much like the original Goblin Trek but in this game the desert itself is hostile and the terrain areas while possibly home to hostile creatures are also the only shelter from the heat of the desert.

Easy to learn with enough variables to make each game a different experience.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Elfs vs Dwarfs: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
Elfs vs Dwarfs is a solo game in which you can play either the Dwarves or the Elves trying to hold out until relieved.

A simple and easy to play game with lots of random options to make each game different.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Czech Legion: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
The Czech Legion famously travelled all the way across Russia during the Russian Civil War
This game represent a small skirmish along the way.

A solo game where you command a small group of soldiers returning from a foraging mission with valuable supplies and being attacked by a force of bandits.

This will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Bagration 1944: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
Bagration 1944 is a solo game where you command a Russian infantry platoon trying to clear out some German forces left behind after your forces rapid advance.

Simple to play.
Will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based, lots of options to keep the game varied each time it is played.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: After Hastings: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
After Hastings is a solo game in which you have to get a small party of Anglo-Danes to safety in the aftermath of the Battle of Hastings, while being pursued by the victorious Norman forces.

Simple to learn and play requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any side will do.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Vikings: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
Vikings is a solo game where you command a group of Vikings cut off and trying to make it to safety while being pursued by lots of angry Anglo Saxons.

A simple game to learn and play but should be lots of fun with plenty of variable factors to make each game different.

Requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any scale will do.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dwarfs Last Stand: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
Dwarfs Last Stand is a solo game you command a small force of Dwarfs attacked by hordes of orcs who can't win.
It is simply a matter of how long you can hold out for.

Easy to learn rules for a fun evenings gaming.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dwarven Beer: A Solo Game
boardgame.description:
Dwarven Beer is a solo game in which you have to transport a wagon full of beer across an area infested with goblins who also want the beer.

You command a small group of Dwarfs plus the beer wagon the goblins are controlled by the rules.

The game has plenty of random factors to keep it different every time you play, easy to learn and fun to play.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Market Trend
boardgame.description:
Market Trend is a market game from Japan, with players working as jewellers. The price of the different gemstones varies according to demand; when players put out new designs and clusters, prices go up, and fall for the gems out of popularity. Players aim to be the richest jeweller by the end of four rounds.

The game has 120 gem cards for different types, from 10 diamonds to 24 jet. The deck is varied for the number of players.

Once the deck is prepared and shuffled, players are dealt 8 hand cards. (If the deck is exhausted leter, discards are shuffled over).

Players then select one card to keep as stock, placing it face-down in front of them, and pass their hand to their neighbour (alternating each round). Then players can sell gems or sets of gems from their hand and make cash.

The value of what they sell is determined by a scoring plan, and alters each round. At the end of the game, there is a final bonus too.

Players can now move the prices of the gem types up or down, according to what they did and did not sell. After this, players are dealt back to 8 cards (or as best can be done), and the game continues.

At the end of the game, the stock cards the players have been collecting are scored for a final bonus. After this, most cash wins.

The distribution of the gem cards matters, and players try to keep in mind which gems they have seen and which have been sold. Understanding which are going to be rarer by the end of the game is a key strategy.
user summary

boardgame.name: Golf Shot Game
boardgame.description:
Players take turns rolling three special six-sided dice with three golf balls, "hook", "slice", and "trap". Each player start with three coins. Each dice roll determines what happens to the coins, either pass a coin to the left (hook), pass a coin to the right (slice), put a coin in the center (trap), or keep the coin (golf ball). Game ends when only one player is left with coins, and he/she wins the coins in the center.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Tower of Dice
boardgame.description:
Tower of Dice is a fast-paced dice rolling dexterity game. The goal is to create a tower of dice faster than your opponent(s) to win the game.

Currently Tower of Dice is a rule set you can download and play yourself at home with 2-6 opponents. You will need a lot of dice...A LOT of dice...depending on the number of players, but two players should get by with 30-40 six-sided dice.

With multiple play modes from basic (stacking dice of like-numbered rolls) to more advanced (using basic math to calculate what your next dice roll should be) the game can satisfy almost any age group for a quick and fun play.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: War Between The Stars
boardgame.description:
The exploration of space was carried out primarily by large corporations which soon found out that valuable resources were few and far between and soon they were in conflict over the few good systems.
After some years things settled down leaving a number of what had become in effect nations looking greedily at each other’s possessions.
The year is 2264 and border skirmishes are common, the discovery of a string of new valuable systems would set off a war that would destroy many of these new nations between the stars.
This war was known as the War of Expansion.

War Between The Stars is a game of starship combat.
It uses a couple of ships or play larger games with whole fleets, lots of ship designs to use as well as a design system to create your own.
There are also a few sample scenarios to get you started and as an introduction to the War of Expansion.

The rule are simple and easy to learn but the use of special features allows for the construction of unique fleets that each has its own advantages.

Sequence of Play:

Starting with whoever has the most ships, the players move alternate ships until all ships have been moved.
Conduct firing, all of which is considered to be simultaneous.
All ships may try to repair damage then
start the next move


—description from the rulebook

boardgame.name: War Between The Stars: Carriers
boardgame.description:
War Between The Stars: Carriers is a supplement for War Between The Stars that introduces the use of Carriers and Fighters into the game.

This is not a stand alone game you will need a copy of War Between The Stars to use it.

Includes some sample ships and a scenario

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: I Need More Trees!
boardgame.description:
A set of rules for fighting the French and Indian Wars ideally using 28mm figures but other scales will work as long as the figures are individually based.

Designed to represent the smaller encounters that took place in the forest using maybe 80-120 figures/side though larger multi player games would also work.

Easy to learn and play these rules should keep you on your toes especially when there are Indians hiding in the forest and you don't know where or how many.

Turn Sequence:

Randomly determine who moves first for the turn
Alternately activate units until all activation points have been used
Test morale for all units that have poor morale

boardgame.name: Spacefighters: War in the Belt
boardgame.description:
As the Earth ran out of resources humanity became more and more dependent on the huge amount of resources available in the asteroid belt. The mining of these was left to a number of corporations that soon started fighting over the most valuable asteroids.
The game represents these encounters between groups of spacefighters played on a hex grid using either counters or model ships normally 2-3 ships/player but larger games are possible and using multiple players will help to model the chaotic nature of these combats.

A set of rules for fighter combat in the asteroid belt.
Needs a hex grid to play and some 10 and 6 sided dice.
You could use counters or models to represent the ships .

The ships are armed with cannons and missiles with limited ammunition so games will come to a natural end rather than continuing until all of one side is destroyed.

Some sample ships are to start with but you can easily design your own.

Turn Sequence:

Roll to recover control
Set ship speed unless out of control
Choose to fly evasive or normal
If not evasive or out of control can roll to repair damage
Move out of controlships
Move evasive ships
Move all other ships
Missiles take effect
Firing with cannons
Firing with missiles


–description from the rulebook

boardgame.name: Subway Network
boardgame.description:
Subway Network is a game from Japan. Players are constructing rail networks in Tokyo or Osaka. By building stations, operating typical businesses on the stations, such as convenience stores, and increasing passengers, players score points to win.

The game has a board on which track cards are placed. Each card has three rail lines in different patterns and hence 6 points of entry/exit. Each card also has two stations, of municipal, dept store or skyscraper types.

The 12 business cards score victory points when built. They come in three types, cafes, retail, and two hotels.

The passenger cards score points when certain conditions are met. For example, 2 points for each municipal station on the line.

Players have their own markers; station, train, and action markers. The train markers go onto spaces around the board, marking the start and finish of their rail lines. The action markers go on an action board, which sets player order. In the round, players move their markers to select their actions in the round.

Players can select a business action, draw business cards and select the one they want, passing the remaining cards to other players who selected the same action. Being able to build a mix of businesses can earn bonus points at the end.

Players can then build out their rail line from hand cards dealt at the start and place a station marker. Completing lines allows a player to recover their markers. After this, some additional actions can be triggered, such as building tunnels.

Then conditions are checked for four open passenger cards. If a card is satisfied, players can score points, and the card is discarded. A fourth card is drawn, until no more are available.

The players action markers are moved back to determine the turn order, and rail cards are dealt back to each player and the game continues.

When the map is filled out, the game ends and players calculate their final scores. The most points wins the game for the best subway network builder.
user summary

boardgame.name: Munchkin Santa-Sized Holiday Grab Box
boardgame.description:
This is a shipping box for Munckin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with special benefits for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. On the box there are various special abilities, such as "Draw one extra treasure when you kill a monster". Each ability has two checkboxes, which have to marked when the bonus is used.

boardgame.name: Munchkin Holiday Grab Box
boardgame.description:
This is a shipping box for Munckin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with special benefits for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. On the box there are various special abilities, such as "Draw one extra treasure when you kill a monster". Each ability has a checkbox, which has to marked when the bonus is used.

boardgame.name: Munchkin Special Delivery
boardgame.description:
This is a shipping box for Munckin - used to ship a bundle of Munchkin items in it.

It comes with a one-time special benefit for the owner, the Twelve Bonuses of Christmas. It says: "You may show this carton to double the treasure for one combat per game, after you have confirmed your victory but before drawing the Treasure cards."

boardgame.name: Orichalcum
boardgame.description:
To find our way home, we must sift through the ruins and our memories of the Empire. But in our remembering, we must not forget what we have created for ourselves.


Orichalcum is a tabletop roleplaying map game for 1-5 players. Players will lay out a map of the Empire that oppressed their ancestors and drowned in a deluge of its own making. By remembering what was left behind, they will draw a connection from the past to the present. Their people, the Exiles, have evolved past the Empire's ways, and these differences will become features on each player's map of their island home. Orichalcum is a game about drowning empires and imagining utopias.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Martian Chariots
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This Starship Builder Kit has been designed to allow you to utilize various stylized starship sections to compile your very own custom starship deckplan. You can use any graphics editing software that support PNG format to combine the pieces, drop them directly into your favorite virtual tabletop (VTT) application, or even print and cut them out to be put together to make a tabletop play map.

This series of kits is designed to allow you to mix-and-match any of the sections included herein with sections included in other sets in the series.

Herein you will find over 20 ship sections including three sample ships built utilizing the included resources are area sections.

With Starship Builder Kits it is easy to create your own high-quality starship deckplans!

boardgame.name: The Old Sandpiper Cottage (PF2)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

An abandoned and derelict cottage along a disused road has some interesting secrets inside...

The Old Sandpiper Cottage (pf2e) is a Pathfinder Second Edition Compatible extended one-shot adventure optimised for 4 players from level 6 and up, but easily adaptable for other levels.

Your fearless adventuring party are travelling from one place to another, maybe on a mission to deliver some goods or information, when they stop at a small village and hear stories of an abandoned cottage not that far away. The local villagers, many of them Dwarven, tell an interesting history. Maybe the party would like to take a look around?

boardgame.name: The Old Sandpiper Cottage (5E)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

An abandoned and derelict cottage along a disused road has some interesting secrets inside...

The Old Sandpiper Cottage (5e) is a 5th Edition Compatible extended one-shot adventure optimised for 4 players from level 8 and up, but easily adaptable for other levels.

Your fearless adventuring party are travelling from one place to another, maybe on a mission to deliver some goods or information, when they stop at a small village and hear stories of an abandoned cottage not that far away. The local villagers, many of them Dwarven, tell an interesting history. Maybe the party would like to take a look around?

boardgame.name: Hellhound Caves: Levels 1 and 2
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

In this first offering, there are two maps and two pages of entries explaining each location. The writing is quick and dirty, giving gamemasters freedom to play fast and loose with the encounters, while still providing enough details to fill an evening game session. The encounters are designed for low-level play, but can easily be adjusted.

boardgame.name: Pristine Underdark River
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Dark tunnels open up to a wide cavern, lit by a glowing blue body of water. Natural stone bridges cross above it, while schools of fish swim below; darting in and out amidst violet and red disk-shaped plants.
The cavern walls are also lined with the strange growths, while purple and red tubular plants glow eerily on the walkways.
Sand and crumbling stone crunch underfoot, and the fish occasionally fly out of the water; calling strangely before diving in again.

boardgame.name: Cold Depths Reef
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on a sand and stone coral shelf. Blue and gray sea life grows off the rocks, inhabited by various types of fish and a shark.
Further down is only the inky dark of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

boardgame.name: Tormentous Tragedies
boardgame.description:
From the description:

Awakening in a Graven-Tosk pit. Carrying a rattling urn. A string of Galgenbeck murders. A green star suspended above in the sky. A crown of stone thorns, tightening with each new dawn.

By default, MÖRK BORG provides twenty terrible tales to burden your party, NPCs, or individual characters with.

Clearly that is not enough.

Herein lie twenty more miserable snippets of narrative to add new and fresh tragedies to your characters' backstories, if they live long enough to see them through.

boardgame.name: Underwater Cavern
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens in this underwater cavern, landing like dappled rainbows on sand and rock shelves. Sharks swim lazily through deep chasms further below, lined with red and purple coral. Higher up, schools of fish dart between hideaways within the rocks. Tubular purple and red growths cluster by natural stone pillars, alongside piles of fallen stone.

Adventure Idea

The scent of the sea is sharp in your nostrils as you approach the docks of a large seaport. But, speaking to the harbormaster to book passage, you learn that all the vessels are landbound. She informs you that monstrously large sharks have been biting holes in their ships, and while there have been many expeditions to kill them, more keep turning up.
Needing passage and unsure what to do, you head to an inn for food and sleep. Inside, you are accosted by a short, balding man with a long, gray beard and a robe he often stumbles over. He explains, in a rather roundabout way, that he’s trying to pay adventurers to seal the cavern network the large sharks come from—but everyone’s been refusing!
You see, he’s a wizard who had a hypothesis that an ancient species of shark (believed to be extinct for millennia) had adapted to survive in warm, underwater tunnels. Everyone thought was mad, so to prove it he opened a hole in them; releasing a veritable torrent of sharks!
While initially he was rather excited to have his theory proven—dismissing years of cajoling from fellow academics—the highly aggressive sharks have since become quite the nuisance. They are, after all, destabilizing the ecosystem, preventing farmers from visiting their oyster farms or fishing, eating all the whales, attacking ships… etc, etc.
As the passage you seek is easiest by ship, you begrudgingly accept. The wizard insists on paying you with a bag of rainbow, supposedly magic jellybeans. He also emphasizes that he doesn’t want you to kill the sharks, just seal them away like before—where they can live in their own microcosm. The wizard then equips you with strange shoes, shaped like seal flippers, as well as three magical orbs to place around the first cavern which will collapse it when the word “Zimzalabim” is said. Lastly, he casts a spell that enables you to breathe and fight in the water as you would on land—though it only lasts for 24 hours.
Before you leave, a villager pulls you aside and discreetly offers a large bag of gold to destroy the sharks inside the cavern network instead. He’s seen the destruction they can do, and doesn’t trust that the blighters won’t escape again.
The ancient sharks are huge. But when you arrive at the entrance to the underwater caverns, you see that the ones inside are even larger—so large they couldn’t leave through the hole the wizard blasted. It appears to be a breeding ground, and a colossal shark is within the area that you’ll have to place the charges.
DM’S NOTES: The underwater cavern network is close to the surface as the sharks thrive in warm, shallow waters. The rocky ceiling is porous, so sunlight still filters down through much of it. The caverns themselves also contain ancient species of giant squid and other whales, which feed upon the smaller fish, shrimp, and—of course—each other.

boardgame.name: Picnic Palace
boardgame.description:
From the description:

Deep in the heart of Mayfield lies an ancient and abandoned picnic site. This was once a destination spot for the giants. In more recent generations, the picnic basket was home to an ant castle but now it is nothing more than an ancient dungeon. What potential treasures and encounters lie deep in this unexplored dungeon crawl?

This Mausritter, third-party supplement, was created for the #MoreMausritterMay Mayfield Game Jam.

boardgame.name: Charlemaus
boardgame.description:
From the description:

Charlemaus, son of Pip the Short, King of the Fikarts became one of the greatest rulers in Mouse history. But alas, history has forgotten his exploits and his treasures are lost amidst the flowering fields!

This Mausritter, third-party supplement, was created for the #MoreMausritterMay Mayfield Game Jam.

boardgame.name: Battlemap Sewers
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Battlemap Sewers is 23x22 in 70 pixels per inch.

boardgame.name: Battlemap Camp (II)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Battlemap Camp is 25x25 in 70 pixels per inch.

boardgame.name: Battlemap Courtyard
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Battlemap Courtyard is 25x25 in 70 pixels per inch.

boardgame.name: Battlemap Lava Cave
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Battlemap Lava Cave is 30x25 in 70 pixels per inch.

boardgame.name: One Shot Village Raid
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

One Shot Village Raid is a one shot adventure set near the border of two kingdoms. The adventure includes adventure text and two maps.

The adventure is designed for a party of 2nd level characters and is expected to take about 4 hours.

boardgame.name: 100 Items in a Wild West Desperado's Pocket
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Desperadoes are bold and violent criminals who were outlaws on the Western frontier of the 19th Century. They could be found holding up stagecoaches, robbing banks, overwhelming local law enforcement in a small town, or just performing simple banditry on the vast trails that cross the continent. And while they might be charming, clever and even handsome, they are often desperate as the forces they have set in motion close in on them.

This list is intended for any Wild West setting (like Tall Tales, Deadlands, Boot Hill, etc.) where the vehicle of choice is the horse, the Colt revolver is King, and there is far more land than there are people. This list can be used with a cooling corpse, an arrested boy who thinks he’s a man, or when a pick pocket decides to test their luck. This roleplaying tool gives you dozens of different ways to add a new dimension to your next outlaw.

boardgame.name: 100 Cyber City Treasures Vol 4: Cred Cards
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Money makes the world go round, but how much can you afford to be caught with when you’re out on the street?

This list is intended for any dark future setting (like Cyberpunk Red, Cyberpunk 2020, Carbon 2185, Shadowrun, Aeon Punk, Altered Carbon, GURPS Cyberpunk, Android, Rifts, etc.) where you don’t want to carry a fat stack of bills.

boardgame.name: 100 Planetary Industries in Deep Space
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Travel across the stars has provided humans and other lifeforms with a great deal of open space at the cost of a great deal of travel. This has lead to the formation of focused hubs of industry where significant groups have consolidated together to maximize all of the opportunities that can exist from drawing in similar resources and skilled beings.

This list is intended for any deep space setting (like Traveller, Star Wars, Star Trek, Space Opera, Rifts, Babylon 5, Red Dwarf, etc.) where technology is not necessarily uniform or simple. This list can be applied to planets, moons, outposts, colonies, space stations, large ships, and so on. This roleplaying tool gives you dozens of different ways to add a new dimension to your next location of note.

boardgame.name: 100 Items in a Tech's Pocket
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Tech is a slang term for an inventor, vehicle mechanic, weaponsmith, scavenger, drone designer, jack of all trades, and freelancer with profound technical training in engineering, design, and crafting. They can build just about anything. Whether they are purely home grown with no cyber augmentation, or mostly metal veterans who look more like a robot than a human, their role can shift the balance of power and provide the gear to defeat the enemy.

This list is intended for any dark future setting (like Cyberpunk 2020, Cyberpunk Red, Shadowrun, Rifts, Carbon 2185, Android, Altered Carbon, etc.) where technology is running rampant, and corporations and criminals are common. This list can be applied to a cooling corpse, an impoverished punk, or a corporate engineer. This roleplaying tool gives you dozens of different ways to add a new dimension to your next mad scientist.

boardgame.name: 100 Fantasy Treasures Vol 2: Furs (Advanced)
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The furs gathered by bow and from trap lines can be harvested and gathered for cape, jackets, coats, robes and blankets that nobles and the casual rich will pay good money for. From common herbivores to uncommon carnivores, this product gives you a wide range of animals and values. This roleplaying tool gives you a fairly robust list for dozens of different ways to add this unique and specific kind of treasure to your next fantasy adventure.

This list is intended for any Fantasy or Western setting (like Dungeons and Dragons, Pathfinder, Tall Tales, Boot Hills, Deadlands, Wild West, etc.) where the wildlife is varied and abundant, and there is no stigma against fur being incorporated into the home and expensive garments. Apply this information to trappers, a mountain man, a newly dead wandering animal, or the attire of the nobility.

boardgame.name: 100 Magical Drink Effects - Vol 1
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

In a world filled with the arcane and the unknown, who can say what happens when we consume magic into ourselves?

This list is intended for any fantasy setting (like Dragons and Dragons, Pathfinder, Runequest, Tunnels and Trolls, etc.) where magic is not necessarily uniform or simple. This list can be applied to magical pools, mystic fountains, potion mixtures, elemental rifts, gnomish mistakes, accidental elixirs, strange elven wines, odd dwarven beers and all manner of alchemical fluids. This roleplaying tool gives you dozens of different ways to add a different dimension to your mystically mysterious liquid. NOTE: Any results marked with an “*” produce instantaneous effects, while the rest of magic situations last for 3d4 minutes unless otherwise noted. All effects are subject to the needs of the Game Master and the story. All saving throws ae subject to the GM’s discretion.

boardgame.name: Skybolt Zack
boardgame.description: Steam description - Skybolt Zack is a brand new fast-paced arcade gaming experience! With his Rocket Punches Zack leaps from enemy to enemy, destroying anything standing in his way! Match the colour of the enemies with the buttons on the gamepad to rid the world of Dr Kaz’s robot army!

boardgame.name: RANK RUNNER
boardgame.description: Steam description - Bullet-hell meets endless runner. LITERALLY ascend the Leaderboard as you play. RANK RUNNER is an intense highscore chaser, wrapped in a neon retro aesthetic. Come run the Leaderboard.

boardgame.name: Hero's Descent
boardgame.description: Steam description - Battle against time in this faced-paced retro-inspired Rogue-like

boardgame.name: At Home Alone
boardgame.description: Steam description - This is a recreational healing Mini-plot game explored at home. Players will play and wander around the house from the perspective of a little girl. What will she do when she is alone? What strange stories will happen in the process, and in the process of exploration, you may find some strange secrets....

boardgame.name: Chindit Game
boardgame.description:
A simple game representing a small group of Chindits trying to reach their base after a mission deep in enemy territory.

The game does not use figures all you need is a piece of paper a pen and a pack of playing cards including the jokers.

Quick and fun to play a game usually lasts less than 10 minutes.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Generica Floorplans Volume 10: Barracks • Lodge
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

GENERICA Floorplans are a combination of traditional 2D maps and 3D visual aids which can help you flesh out your campaign setting. Generic fantasy town locations (such as Taverns, Temples and Shops) are showcased with carefully designed floorplans and 3D rendered views to provide your players with a more immersive gaming experience.

Each GENERICA Floorplans volume contains one 3D Exterior Mapview, two isometric top-down Floorplan Maps, as well as additional 3D renders of Interior Mapviews. Each download also includes two full-sized gameplay maps designed to be printed at 16” x 20”.

boardgame.name: Geographica Continents Vol. 2-A
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Need a homebrew world map but lack significant drawing skills? Need a detailed continent map calling out specific biomes, but don’t have the time or money to spend on complex mapping software? Hinterland Mapview’s GEOGRAPHICA map series can jump start your creative process by providing you with a variety of generic full color geographical maps.

Each full color GEOGRAPHICA map delineates grasslands, desert sands, heavily forested areas, mountainous regions, landforms trapped beneath glacial ice, and depicts prominent rivers and lakes as well. Each map is essentially a blank slate for you to place cities and towns wherever you wish. Each color map is accompanied by a black & white version delineating only mountains and rivers, allowing you to sketch out your own national boundaries and clearly label prominent landmarks yourself.

boardgame.name: Black Seas: Large Xebec
boardgame.description:
A Xebec is a two- or three-masted vessel usually found in the Mediterranean that was used mostly for trading. It had a long overhanging bowsprit, an aftset mizzen mast and lateen sails.

Favoured by Barbary Corsairs (Muslim pirates operating off the coast of North Africa) and Algerian Berber corsairs, early xebecs had two masts, whilst later examples had three. The ships were generally smaller than frigates of the period, both in terms of displacement and the number of guns they carried.

The modified ships were oftentimes faster than their victims owing to a narrower floor, and their lateen sails meant that it could sail at great speed close to the wind – lending them a great advantage in pursuit or escape. Xebecs armed in this way would mount between 300 and 400 men and would mount between 16 and 40 guns.

The design was not without its disadvantages; the ships fared poorly in rough weather and high seas, and the sails were vulnerable to enemy dismantling fire. A wise captain would therefore need to pick their battles wisely, and use their ship’s superior manoeuvrability to avoid unwinnable confrontations and instead prey on the weak – striking swiftly to overwhelm their prey and withdraw equally as quickly.

As well as uses in piracy there were some uses of xebecs in national navies as light warships – often as a direct counter to the pirates themselves. The advantages of speed and manoeuvrability did not go unnoticed by coastal traders either – especially those who favoured speed and draft over cargo capacity.

One of the most famous single-ship actions in all of naval history involved a Xebec. On 6 May 1801, the British sloop Speedy defeated the Spanish Xebec-frigate El Gamo. This engagement is the inspiration for many examples of literary naval fiction, perhaps most notably Patrick O’Brian’s Master and Commander.

This pack includes one large Xebec for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for its use with the included ship card.

–description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Black Seas: Large Galley
boardgame.description:
Though galleys were out of favour by the Age of Sail, they were still used. Galleys are very low, long, and slender ships that use banks of oars as their main mode of propulsion. Identified easily by their long hulls and shallow drafts, they still maintained sails that could be used should the winds prove favourable – though this never superseded manpower as the primary means of manoeuvrability.

In Black Seas, galleys can deploy oars and, if needed, move independently of the wind. While moving under oars, these ships can move as if at Battle Sails, no matter where the wind is coming from. However, as the crew is busy rowing, the ship will shoot with an additional -2 penalty. Galleys may also deploy their sails, following the same rules as all other sailing ships. However, in order to switch from sails to oars, or vice versa, a ship must spend one full Turn without shooting.

Originating in the Mediterranean by the early naval powers – notably the Greeks, Illyrians, Phoenicians, and Romans, the galley remained the predominantly used types of vessels used for both war and piracy in those seas until the end of the 16th century. Though the advent of the lateen sail used in hybrid vessels like xebecs had displaced the use of galleys by the 18th century, the vessels still saw some use. The last recorded battle where galleys took a significant part in the Mediterranean was at Matapan in 1717; however, the vessels enjoyed a brief resurgence in the wars of the 18th century between Russia, Sweden and Denmark.

This pack includes one large galley for inclusion in Black Seas fleets. You’ll find rules for its use with the included ship card.

–description from the publisher

boardgame.description:

The Mine 45x45 Battlemap

Little bit of a showcase of our new Mine assets

boardgame.name: Infinite Forest 25x25 Battlemap
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Considering how common and versatile forests are in tabletop RPGs, It’s surprisingly hard to find a large, high quality forest map.

So I’ve decided to make 4 for you guys! Each map is 25×25 (A,B,C,D) and they seamlessly connect to each other.

Resulting 50×50 Forest map is seamlessly tile-able so you can have literal Infinite forest, if you wish

All maps come in 3 variants – “Original”, Fall/Autumn, Feywild

Hope you’ll find these useful!

boardgame.name: Corrupted Giant's Lair 50x30 Battlemap
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A Giant was corrupted by a strange crystal and is now wreaking havoc on nearby settlements, kidnapping villagers and sacrificing their souls to the crystal. Growing stronger with each sacrifice!

There is a small “prisoner” area in the top right for a special someone that he kidnapped but doesn’t want to sacrifice for some reason, who might that prisoner be? and why was he spared?

This was a lot of fun to make and we hope you guys like it!

boardgame.name: A History of Witchcraft, Volume 1
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A system-agnostic sourcebook for any historical, horror, or fantasy game.

This History of Witchcraft is a system-agnostic sourcebook for any historical, horror, or fantasy game. In four volumes it presents a real-world account of witchcraft in England between 1558 to 1718. Based on the academic work of Wallace Notestein, it focuses on the political and cultural causes and impacts of witchhunters and witch trials, rather than strictly religious or supernatural factors.

The result is a rich, nuanced look at the period filled with information, which can be mined for worldbuilding details usable in your own settings. There are colorful characters that can be adapted as villains and non-player characters. Story hooks abound, either as background details for your game world, or as adventure seeds for player characters to pursue.

In presenting the Witchcraft Reference series, my goal is to get people to look beyond official gaming material for inspiration. There is a wealth of ideas to be found in history, biographies, and older fiction from before the tabletop roleplaying game era that is waiting to be tapped. My hope is that this book with fire up your imagination, and help you to discover new possibilities.

boardgame.name: Dinosaur Hunting!
boardgame.description:
In the 1920's a valley was found full of Dinosaurs.
Soon hunters were heading there to try their luck at BIG big game hunting.

Lead a small group of hunters and see who can get the most trophies or indeed just survive.

Ideal for 28mm figures but will work with any size of figures just use what you have available.

Turn:

Randomly determine the order in which the players activate each turn.
The dinosaurs all activate after the players.
On their turn a player activates each figure which can make two actions (move, fire, load or observe) They can do the same action twice if they want but there may be penalties for doing this.


–description from the publisher and the rulebook

boardgame.name: Medieval Origins, Volume 1
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The object of the Medieval Origins series is to show the things that had to happen prior to the Middle Ages in order for that period to unfold the way it did. The Greeks and their mythologies, the Romans and their Empire, and the rise of Christianity all had to exist in order for what we think of as Medievalism to come about. The earlier events contextualize the period, and allow us to make sense of some of the strange, brutal, and beautiful things we think of when we talk about Medieval Europe.

Understanding the origins of the medieval period can help us to become better worldbuilding and gamemasters. We can craft better adventures, not just by cannibalizing and remixing tales from history, but through understanding the connections between historical events. Having a grasp of history can even help us to create better characters, but connecting them to richer back stories, understanding the cultural, religious, and political motivations for their actions, and giving them a grander sense of purpose.

boardgame.name: Discovery of Witches
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A Brief History of Matthew Hopkins, Witchfinder General

You can’t discuss the history of witchcraft without bringing up witch hunters, and you can talk about witch hunters and leave out the Witchfinder General himself, Matthew Hopkins. The volume you’re reading right now contains his classic treatise, The Discovery of Witches. Nominally an explanation of how Hopkins identified who was a witch, it reads more like an FAQ on why witchfinding is totally not a scam and Hopkins is absolutely legitimate and not a grifter. It’s easy to envision him not as any sort of holy man or even a soldier, but as a kind of bard. One that spun his own lore virtually from whole cloth, in order to inspire panic and convince people to pay him for the humble, if homicidal, service of making the problem go away.

This version has been translated, not exactly into modern English but into language that makes sense to modern readers. It’s not even a matter of archaic words and dated grammar. In the original, Hopkins was prone to spelling the same word multiple ways and abbreviating things inconsistently. While cleaning things up I was careful to not alter the meaning of the text, but in places it does read like satire. I assure you, Hopkins was deathly serious.

The second part of the book is a biography of Hopkins, written by noted historian Wallace Notestein. It gives you some background on the man, the times he lived in, and the circumstances under which he operated his completely real and not at all fraudulent witchfinding business.

In the final section, James Grant looks at the legacy of the witchfinders, including Hopkins. The fear and superstition that they spread had an impact on society for decades to come. One has to wonder about the long-lasting effects of modern-day misinformation and the scare tactics used by 21st century grifters. What claims will stick and become part of the culture, in spite of how ridiculous and easy to disprove they are? In this way, the themes that exist within the witchfinder narratives can be used as fodder for stories and in any genre, not just historical dramas or fantasy adventures.

boardgame.name: A Pirates' Who's Who, Volume 1: Aisa-Cooper
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This version of The Pirates’ Who’s Who, presented in 4 volumes, was edited with the creative tabletop roleplayer in mind. It provides an overview of the topic of piracy, and discussed the way its history has been documented. There’s a lot of information, but not so much that it overwhelms, or leaves no space to unleash your own creativity.

This book is a great source of character names. That some people get only a line or two, while others get detailed biographies that go on for pages, has been inspirational and validating. My own notebooks are filled with non-player characters similarly documented. I’ve always given myself guilt for not fleshing all of them out equally. Like my supporting cast, many of the personages named here don’t even have full names. Some are simply a last name. That gives you the opportunity to “borrow” them, and mold them into the character you need them to be.

What I love most about this book, though, are the stories. Some are complete, but many beg other questions. As roleplaying fodder, those loose ends give me something to work with. Some of the information presented boils down to interesting worldbuilding details, which can be used to flesh out a piratical setting.

boardgame.name: Gamemaster Guide - Hippogryph
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

As the gamemaster, you are the prime mover behind any Hippogryph game. You create and shape the setting that the characters inhabit, and prepare and run the adventures they’ll go on. It’s your role to tell the story, play the supporting characters, and manage the dynamics of the group. To do this, you have to knowing what your players want from a Hippogryph experience. It’s a big job, but an incredibly rewarding one.

The Hippogryph Gamemaster Guide assumes that you already have a copy of the core rules and know how the Hippogryph System works. You don’t need to be an expert, or have every single mechanic and guideline committed to memory. All you need is a firm grasp of the fundamentals, so you can make fair rulings, teach new players how things work, and keep a game session flowing smoothly.

boardgame.name: Gamemaster Guide - DoubleZero
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

As the gamemaster, you are the prime mover behind any DoubleZero game. You create and shape the setting that the characters inhabit, and prepare and run the adventures they’ll go on. It’s your role to tell the story, play the supporting characters, and manage the dynamics of the group. To do this, you have to knowing what your players want from a DoubleZero experience. It’s a big job, but an incredibly rewarding one.

The DoubleZero Gamemaster Guide assumes that you already have a copy of the core rules and know how the DoubleZero System works. You don’t need to be an expert, or have every single mechanic and guideline committed to memory. All you need is a firm grasp of the fundamentals, so you can make fair rulings, teach new players how things work, and keep a game session flowing smoothly.

boardgame.name: How to Gamemaster
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

My first experience with tabletop a roleplaying games was as the gamemaster. It was 1979, and my friends and I had pooled our money to buy the Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set. None of us had ever played before. There was no one else to run for us, or teach us how things were supposed to work. I read the rules and made up some characters, but I had no idea what I was supposed to do. After picking some monsters that looked cool to fight, and drawing a rudimentary map, I made it up as I went along. It was a lot of fun, but it took a while before I felt like I knew what I was doing.

If I’d had a book to show me what to do, I wouldn’t have spent so much time figuring things out on my own. I could have been sharpening other skills, rather than sorting out what the fundamentals were. That’s why I wrote How to Gamemaster. It’s my attempt to create the how-to manual I wish I’d had over 40 years ago.

boardgame.name: Building Worlds 2
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Worldbuilding can be a lot of fun. Whether you're planning a campaign, designing your own tabletop roleplaying game, or just exercising your creativity with no set purpose in mind, developing a setting of your very own is deeply satisfying. You can spend hours, days, or years adding details and creating a world with no limits but your imagination.

Building Worlds 2 contains a series of prompts to help you increase the breadth and depth of your roleplaying setting. Develop every area of your setting, or just focus on the element you'll need for player character backgrounds and the campaigns you plan to run. This book shows you how to draw worldbuilding ideas from the system of your choice, and how to use character options, implied setting features, and the events of adventures to expand the setting into the world of your dreams.

boardgame.name: Left 4 Dead Jump
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

What the hell happened?

Why is everything on fire?

And what is that moa-

boardgame.name: Ready Player One Jump
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The year is 2039 CE. The place, Earth, in the midst of an ongoing energy crisis that sees rolling blackouts hitting major cities on a weekly, if not daily basis. It is a world in the grip of climate collapse, economic collapse, and even social collapse, with the areas between cities (what cities that haven’t been nuked out of existence) having largely descended into lawlessness and brigandage.

boardgame.name: Cthulhu Saves the World
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The legends speak of an Ancient Evil known only as ‘Cthulhu’. It is said to have come to this Earth from beyond the Heavens… For eons, Cthulhu ruled from atop the great city of R’lyeh. While the legends are silent to the fall of Great R’lyeh… They all foretold the same prophecy:

Cthulhu will rise again.

boardgame.name: Ctrl CV
boardgame.description: A little 2D platforming game where the twist that that your sprite looks identical to the other hundreds of identical AI sprites that move throughout the level just like you.

boardgame.name: Ginga Force
boardgame.description:
Ginga Force (ギンガフォース Ginga Fōsu) is a shoot'em up game developed by Qute Corporation and released in the XBOX 360 console in 2013.

Ginga Force is a vertical Shoot ’em Up at its core, with an added focus towards immersive storytelling. Set on the planet Seventia in a distant future, you will join forces with Alex and Margaret, two exceptional pilots who are tasked to guard the planet from an intimidating collection of criminals and terrorists.

boardgame.name: Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Annihilageddon 2 – Xtreme Nacho Legends
boardgame.description:
Return to the arena for the second insane deck-building game from the award-winning Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards universe! The action is even more intense, the carnage is more vicious, and the table-flipping anger is even more epic.

Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Annihilageddon 2 – Xtreme Nacho Legends is a standalone game, but it's also compatible with Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards: Annihilageddon, the first deck-building game in the Epic Spell Wars universe!

boardgame.name: Wizard's Vengeance
boardgame.description:
From the publishers blurb:

The wizard is dead - burnt at the stake by a menacing witch hunter. His tower is unguarded and ripe for plunder. Gold, artifacts and magic can be yours, if you act swiftly. But will you be able to get away with the loot? For even in death the wizard will exact his vengeance!

This Old School Renaissance adventure will take you through 10 floors and 25 rooms of a wizard's tower, full of traps, monsters and eldritch artifacts. It is suitable for a party of any level. Depending on the strength and ingenuity of the party, they can either loot whatever falls in their hands or try to take over the tower itself. The default setting is mything Europe of 16/17the century, but the module can be easily adjusted to other fantasy locales.

boardgame.name: The LOOP: Die Rache von Foozilla
The LOOP: La Revanche de Foozilla
The LOOP: The Revenge of Fauxzilla
boardgame.description:
The first expansion for The LOOP brings new characters, equipments and game modes.

Your favorite evil genius, Dr. Faux, returns with a terrifying giant monster, Fauxzilla!
Will you let him wreck the Universe?

Play as two new agents, the young Dr. Faux himself and the Peak Twins, to foil his plans in two new game modes.
Dr. Faux is back, and he's unleashed the wrath of Fauxzilla.

This giant monster will soon be rampaging through space-time! The Agency has no choice but to convince the legendary Peak Twins and Faux Klein Schlag to return to action!

Take on Dr. Faux's not-so-domestic giant monster, Fauxzilla, in two new game modes: "Fauxzillapocalypse" puts you on a time-track to defeat the beast. To defeat it, charge and set off powerful energy traps at the right time.

In "The 7 Kaiju Balls", retrieve Fauxzilla's Eggs through time to seal them in their proper era, while dodging the monster's fury.

You can now count on two new characters: Faux Klein Schlag, a young version of Dr. Faux himself, determined to regain the upper hand over his evil future self. And the Peak Twins, the most feared pair of enforcers in the Middle Ages.

New Artifacts and 2 additional Sabotage tiles will take your Loop experience to the next level!

Requires the base game to play.

— Description from the publisher.

Sonst würde es ja langweilig werden und du müsstest für die Chefin der Agentur Kaffee kochen! Was nie langweilig ist, war und wird, ist das: Dr. Foos durchgeknallte Pläne zu sabotieren. boardgame.name: Trouble in Wealdham
boardgame.description:
Save an unwitting hamlet from an undead threat!

Wealdham is a sleepy, quiet town located in the Westwood.
Nothing ever happens in Wealdham, until Waterdeep necromancer Faurius Besk decides to test his latest invention near the town...

Trouble in Wealdham is a 4 hour adventure for Tier 1 Characters (optimized for APL 3). It can be run as a one-shot, as part of an existing campaign, or even to launch a new campaign to defeat Faurius. Chapter 5 includes a section on how to weave this adventure into a new or existing campaign.

boardgame.name: Clash of Galliformes
boardgame.description:
On Kickstarter June 15th (2022)

Explore, build and battle in this strategy and resource management game with ground-living birds set in an alternate timeline where birds work alongside tribal clans. As the clans have developed close to their feathery mounts, their cultures have been formed by their specific clan birds. Some have mastered the way of faster bird breeding while others have gone down a more warlike path. Now is the time to choose your bird and in so doing, your way of life.

Players must expand their territory to find supplies and new technologies for their tribes. The threat from rival clans is also constant, so you have to adapt your strategies and think ahead of your opponents to survive. Will you conquer the other clans by force or will your memory live on through the peaceful measure of completing cave paintings? The choice is yours!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Tranquility: The Ascent – Friends in High Places Promo
boardgame.description: Included for all Kickstarter backers of Tranquility: The Ascent, and with limited availability post-campaign, the Friends in high places adds five unique player powers to the game. Shuffle the powers as part of the setup and deal one randomly to each player. They now have access to one powerful ability that may make the difference between winning and losing.

An ancient, ruined stronghold, now occupied by dangers!

SubLevel 2 - Great hall, filled with Dragon gold
SubLevel 3 - Old barracks, with evidence of last stand
SubLevel 4 - Ruined entrance to mine
SubLevel 5 - Throne room of a ratking

boardgame.name: Storriah's Observatory
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Watching the stars and skies...
Storriah's Observatory is a printable battemap compatible with any RPG game. It can be used as a standalone gameboard, or combined with any same-scale tileset.

Storriah's Observatory is a day & night set, comprising of 2 30x30 battlemaps. An observatory with a fancy telescope is set up on a natural rocky height, with smaller buildings serving as quarters and studies.

boardgame.name: Gjorn
boardgame.description:
Gjorn is a fast, quick-to-learn but very tactical card game for 2-4 players. You will win by making tactical decisions. You need to get ahead of your opponent to dominate the battlefield.

There are five different kinds of cards and each card has its own effect.

There are also 2 kinds of tokens coins and fame. Some of the card effects make you lose coins, but you can never lose fame.

You win by collecting coins and fame. Both are worth 1 point

Card effects:

Axe: Capture 3 coins

Shield: Opponents lose 2 coins

Bow: Capture 1 coin and make your opponent lose 1 coin

Horn: Earn 1 fame

Runestone: Win every tie.

Starting the game:
You shuffle all the cards together and every player gets 7 cards. There are 15 rounds now.

In each round, players place a card face down in front of them and reveal it at the same time.

Players compare all their cards in front of them. And whoever has the most cards of a type, or a tie but most runestones, get the effect of the card.

Who has the most points at the end wins.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Fighter Archetypes: Guard, Mercenary, Raider
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This file covers the most common fighting styles and fighter archetypes in Amazons Vs Valkyries.

Features:

3 new Fighting Styles: Mounted Combat, Phalanx Fighting, and Skirmisher
The Guard: A protective fighter who can use her shield as a weapon
The Mercenary: A versatile and adaptable fighter
The Raider: A fighter specialized in asymmetric warfare and sabotage

boardgame.name: The Dath
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

One People. Many Divisions.

Once a single race, the Dath have been split into a collection of sub-races defined by the color of their skin and their awesome magical powers. With a (mostly) unified culture, the Dath are ready to be dropped into your next game! Enjoy this vibrant race, with powers as diverse as their hues!

Includes:

Racial Traits For 6 Primary Colors: The main sub-races of the Dath, from the olympian blues to the stoic yellows! Each has a unique power that makes them compelling to play both in and out of combat!
Racial Traits For 9 Hues: Even more sub-races birthed by the mixing of colors! Each blends the aesthetic of two primary colors to form a new sub-race!

boardgame.name: The Last Bridge Inn
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Along the Old King’s Highway is a bridge. It’s only a few miles before the road fades into an overgrown
cart track the ends at the West Gate of Gun Lodir, under Mount Burimm Begh. Though the Highway has run to ruin, enough folk still travel that way—mostly dwarven traders out of Gun Lodir—that the bridge over White Run is kept ingood repair.

Next to the Last Bridge is an inn. Thick stone walls enclose a large courtyard in which is set a fine house with real glass in the tall windows and a set of double doors that usually stand open. Smoke always rises from the chimney, carrying the smell of roasting venison across the Highway when the wind is right...

boardgame.name: Thompson's Gold
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A convoy is coming soon to Desert-city, you know it.
However, the stagecoach attack takes an unexpected turn when you discover its cargo...
With whom to ally, who to have as enemies, and above all:
who pays the best?


Un convois arrive bientôt à Desert-city, vous le savez.
Pourtant, l'attaque de diligence prend un tour inattendu quand vous découvrez sa cargaison…
Avec qui s'allier, qui avoir comme ennemis, et surtout :
qui paie le mieux ?

boardgame.name: Lights & Illuminations (5E)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of tools to help you give your dungeons sources of illumination. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Lights & Illuminations is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Lights & Illuminations (OSR)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of tools to help you give your dungeons sources of illumination. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Lights & Illuminations is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Lights & Illuminations (PF1)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of tools to help you give your dungeons sources of illumination. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Lights & Illuminations is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: Lights & Illuminations (PF2)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This instalment of Dungeon Dressing presents loads of tools to help you give your dungeons sources of illumination. Designed to be used both during preparation or actual play, Dungeon Dressing: Lights & Illuminations is an invaluable addition to any GM's armoury!

boardgame.name: One Hundred Plus Dungeon Concepts
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is a quick and easy tool to generate some dungeon ideas for your upcoming fantasy gaming sessions. Simply roll on the tables and let your imagination run wild – you'll have a memorable dungeon concept in no time!
Presented here are 100 of the most classical dungeon locations in fantasy roleplaying. Most of it purposefully mundane, but there are some supernatural elements mixed in.
This is a basic tool that a GM can use for all their roleplaying and dungeon crawling campaign prep.

1d100 dungeon locations
Supernatural / magic references are kept to a bare minimum – gives you full control of the tone of your game
Includes 3 additional support tables
Perfect for slice of life, OSR, historical and medieval fantasy games
System Agnostic – use with your favorite RPGs

boardgame.name: Disasters
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Following Starfleet’s mandate of exploration in any era of play, including The Next Generation era, is a noble pursuit not without risk. Space is massive, filled with as many potentially amazing discoveries as it is full of nightmarish death traps and disasters waiting to challenge an unprepared crew. Space exploration is for the bold, not the faint of heart, and even then, the boldest of explorers cannot prepare for every possible contingency.

This packet presents ten detailed mission briefs oriented around potential disasters you can modify for use as adventures in your Star Trek Adventures campaigns set during The Next Generation era (approximately 2360-2379). Each mission brief is designed to stand alone, though they could be strung together into a story arc or added to an existing campaign with minor modifications.

boardgame.name: Growing Pains
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The years immediately following the formation of the United Federation of Planets in 2161 were fraught with challenges for new Starfleet crews, whether they were pushing the boundaries of explored space or developing relationships with the many species that chose to join the newly formed Federation. Former adversaries became allies, and a multitude of species had to learn how to work together.

boardgame.name: Obsession: Useful Box
boardgame.description:
The Obsession: Useful Box contains new content such as promo Gentry cards, Improvement Tiles, Rule cards for new content, Solo Opponent cards for Upstairs, Downstairs, as well as several updated or corrected content from the base game and the Wessex and Upstairs, Downstairs expansions.

The full list of changes is detailed in this thread:
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/2647648/useful-box

boardgame.name: Waggle Dance
boardgame.description: Control worker bees to build a beehive, collect nectar, and make honey while also being efficient and strategic to outmanoeuvre your opponents. This 1-4 player Euro-style worker-placement dice game has stunning artwork and broad appeal. There are many paths to a sweet victory - it’s every beehive for themselves!

boardgame.name: Once Upon A Crime
boardgame.description: Once Upon a Crime is a party game based on the new "criminal storytelling" mechanic that combines deduction, bluffing and "StoryTelling" in a crime scenario. A player invents a crime by connecting a suspect, a motive, a weapon and a location using the cards on the table and reveals a single clue: who died. The other players must deduce the correct combination by choosing among 4 suspects, 4 motives, 4 weapons and 4 locations. But one or more of the players might be criminals, and they will try to trick them without getting caught.

boardgame.name: Soda Smugglers
boardgame.description:
Lawmakers are cracking down on soda, and tight regulation has made way for lucrative smuggling. One bottle per person is the new law — thus bribes, suitcase inspections, and arrests are on the agenda. Only one will emerge the Soda Kingpin.

Each round in Soda Smugglers, one player takes a turn in the role of a border guard while the other players act as travelers. In a quest to acquire coveted carbonation and its accompanying bottle caps, the border guard tries to confiscate as many sodas as possible while only the cleverest travelers will sneak across with their fizzy contraband. After each player has been the border guard (twice in a 3-4 player game, once in a 5-8 player game), the game ends and whoever has the most bottle caps wins!

—description from the publisher
